entries.title: Iowa Birth and Early Years
entries.description: Lindy Achen began his life in 1902, born on October 7th in Remsen, Iowa. These early years were formative, setting the stage for his later experiences. Though brief, this period marks the beginning of his journey before his family's move to Canada.

excerpts.text: and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.

entries.title: Early Years: Iowa to Saskatchewan
entries.description: These early years (1905-1907) were formative for Lindy, spent in Remsen, Iowa, before a significant family relocation. His memories of this period are fragmented, hinting at a childhood abruptly interrupted by the move to Saskatchewan. The transition marked the beginning of his life on the Canadian prairies, a defining experience for the young boy.

excerpts.text: - be a long drawn-out affair as my memory goes back to the year 1907 when
Oh, when we came to Halbrite in 1907, it was about 700 people.
And now we're talking into 1905.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Work and Growing Up
entries.description: From 1911 to 1916, young Lindy Achen experienced the hard realities of farm life on the Canadian prairies. He worked alongside his family, digging post holes and helping build a new barn, all while navigating the challenges of a demanding rural existence. These years shaped his work ethic and established a foundation for his future endeavors.

excerpts.text: he put down the foundation everything then we had to haul all those rock in to fill that foundation in and then filled it up with sand so they could put a four inch coat of cement all over the barn it was an up-to-date barn everything was first class. That's when I was 13 years old that fall, the fall of 1915. You want to know about work, well that was work and that same
And as soon as we were able to work, I can remember when they built that pasture in 1914, I guess it was, that they used to haul us a mile and a half away, and we'd dig post holes all day
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
In the summer when I was, what, 1915, I was 13 years old that fall.
I think it was the winter of '16 when J.P. was married.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Shadows of 1917
entries.description: For Linden Achen, 1917 marked a difficult period on the family farm in Saskatchewan. Recurring references to the year suggest hardship and potentially a poor harvest, compounded by the looming threat of the 1918 flu pandemic. He was a young teenager, experiencing the challenges of prairie life and the uncertainties of a changing world.

excerpts.text: Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
Then, '17 is a short crop, '18 was a short crop.
1917, bad, kind of a bad year.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Flu and Tractors
entries.description: In 1918, sixteen-year-old Lindy Achen continued to work on his family's farm in Saskatchewan, facing a short harvest and the devastating impact of the influenza pandemic which arrived in the spring. His father purchased a Titan tractor during this time, marking a shift in farm technology, while the family relied on livestock and resourcefulness to overcome hardships and maintain their livelihood.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
And Dad bought a... Oh, in the meantime, 1918, he had bought a little Titan tractor.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Drought and Grasshoppers
entries.description: During 1919-1920, seventeen and eighteen-year-old Lindy Achen experienced severe drought conditions on the family farm in Saskatchewan, leading to drastically reduced crop yields. The situation was further compounded in 1920 by a devastating grasshopper infestation that nearly wiped out their harvest, highlighting the precariousness of life on the prairie.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
In 1920, the grasshoppers came in, and they just really come in clouds, you know, ... poison a whole quarter section.
1920, the hoppers came in and just about cleaned us out.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Changing Times
entries.description: In 1921, Lindy was a young man of nineteen, deeply involved in the family farm in Saskatchewan. He managed the thrashing outfit and experienced a relatively good harvest, though challenges remained. This year also marked significant changes: his father purchased new equipment, a brother left for the coast, and Lindy experienced the novelty of radio.

excerpts.text: But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
And then it was the fall of '21. Dad bought a little separator to go with the little Titan tractor we had.
And as it was then, that was '21. Then that fall, Joe left. He went to the coast.
I was running the thrashing outfit, and I run that same outfit then in 1921.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Growing Skills
entries.description: In 1922, Lindy was a young man of twenty, living on the family farm in Saskatchewan. He experienced a successful harvest and spent time alone with his brother, Mac, while also beginning to learn the skills necessary to maintain the family's rural telephone system. This period marked a time of learning and responsibility on the prairie farm.

excerpts.text: In the winter of '22, I came to Regina and took a telephone course in order to be able to maintain the telephones at home, the local rural telephone.
Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I heard my first radio.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.
'22, we had a bumper crop.

entries.title: Prairie Bounty and Mother's Journey
entries.description: In 1923, Lindy was a young man of 21, experiencing a period of agricultural prosperity on the family farm in Saskatchewan. This year was marked by a significant family event: his mother's departure for California, and the early adoption of new technology like the radio. The good harvest and emerging modern conveniences likely contrasted with underlying familial tensions that would eventually lead him to leave the farm.

excerpts.text: Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I heard my first radio.
And the winter of twenty - the fall of '23, mother went to California.
Yeah, we got a radio about 1923, I think, the first out.
The fall of '23, Mother had gone to California.
And in '23, we were having good crops,

entries.title: Loss, Farm, and Responsibility
entries.description: 1924 was a pivotal year for Lindy, marked by the sudden death of his father. At just 22 years old, he was thrust into the responsibility of managing the family farm in Saskatchewan, following the funeral and his mother's arrival from Portland. This year also signifies the completion of a project, and the beginning of his tenure as the farm's primary operator.

excerpts.text: mother,  mother got there by train it's funny how you could move around in those days. She'd come all the way from portland and we only held the funeral two days, I think. She was there for the funeral. And then I was in charge of the farm starting right then and there so that was in 1924 and uh
I have a few minutes to go before I go for coffee, so I'll just continue about the years before 1924.
I'm getting the story a bit mixed up, but I'll go back to 1924.
That was the summer of 1924, my first year of running the farm.
And, oh yes, in '24, in '24, yeah, we had finished.

entries.title: Prairie Harvests and Power Lines
entries.description: From 1925 to 1928, Lindy Achen experienced good harvests on the family farm in Saskatchewan, but tensions with his brothers led him to leave the farm. He transitioned into the power business around 1927, marking a significant shift from farming to a career as an electrician and the beginning of his long involvement with rural electrification.

excerpts.text: I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
'26, some of the boys came up from California, and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.
The old line, which had been built in 1928, we had a salvage 60 miles a line.
So that's the way it went from - a lifetime in power from 1928 to 1965.
The power commission didn't start until 1928 when it was formed.

entries.title: Wandering the Prairie States
entries.description: 1929 found Lindy Achen traversing the American prairie states of Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota, and North Dakota, seeking work and a new beginning. Following a departure from his family farm in Saskatchewan, he was 27 years old and establishing himself, ultimately ending up in Esseland. This period marked a significant transition in his life, moving away from the family farm and towards a career in construction.

excerpts.text: I started in Iowa, went to Nebraska, then South Dakota, then North Dakota, and finally I wound up at Esseland in 1929.
In 1929, I was 27 years old at that time.
That was the spring of '29.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Early Struggles
entries.description: In 1930, Lindy Achen was working for a Power Corporation, earning 82 cents an hour while covering his own expenses. He was involved in operating a plant that was later shut down due to the construction of a new line, and he began to witness the early effects of the Depression while working in Biggar. This period marked a transition from farm life to a career in electrical work, setting the stage for his future construction endeavors.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
Okay, so now you were in, you were saying, working for the Power Corporation in 1930, and you had a room and board, did you?
The first that I noticed of the Depression was in the fall of '30, we were working in Biggar.
Okay, now you said, okay, you were in 1930 and you were working for the Power Corporation.
In 1930, when I started Estevan, I was making 82 cents an hour and paying my own keep.

entries.title: Prairie Roots, Electric Beginnings
entries.description: In 1931, Lindy Achen was navigating a pivotal period after leaving the family farm and establishing himself as an electrician. He began working for the Power Commission, a venture that ended abruptly with a leave of absence, and also undertook early electrical wiring projects. These years also saw him traveling, including a trip to Iowa and returning his mother, marking a time of both professional development and familial connection.

excerpts.text: And when I think back through the years from about '31 when I started working for the Power Commission, and I mentioned that earlier, and then I only worked for them eight months, and I took a leave of absence and I never went back.
I'll tell you where I noticed it most during the years, like I went to Iowa in 1931 and then I took my mother down again in 1938.
If you talk about unemployment, I'll get back to that when I was in Saskatoon in the spring of '31.
I think I related earlier that I had started doing some inside wiring way back in 1931.
I went up there in January of '31.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Rest, Work, and Wiring
entries.description: Between 1932 and 1934, Lindy Achen found himself largely unemployed and at home on the family farm in Saskatchewan. He briefly worked at Tompkins and for a power company in Estevan, building power lines and gaining experience. This period marked a transition towards his career as an electrician, culminating in encouragement to pursue his journeyman's papers in the fall of 1934.

excerpts.text: it's conditions are so bad for it now. When I went into this small town of Tompkins to build a power line in the fall of '33 in that small town there were about 300 maybe 275 300 people living there, and I went in there by myself.
It was in 1934 that the electrician - the inspector who used to come through there said to me one day, "Why don't you write your journeyman's paper?" he said, "You're a good electrician."
And then the spring of '34, Dubois, the superintendent, this was still the same company that was in Estevan, he said, "I'm putting you down in Gull Lake to do some wiring there.
Yeah, then in '34, then the same company said they'd put me into Gull Lake rewiring buildings, business places that were
And into '33, then the power company in Estevan phoned me up one day and asked me to come down for about a month.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Shifting Lines
entries.description: Between 1935 and 1938, Lindy Achen worked as an electrician and power plant operator in Saskatchewan, experiencing both the challenges of rural electrification and the hardships of the Dust Bowl migration. He moved frequently, working in various locations including Shaunavon, Assiniboia, Rosetown, and Gravelbourg, often dealing with temporary assignments and the abandonment of small power plants due to larger infrastructure projects.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
And then in '36, they decided they were going to run a power line from Gull Lake to Tompkins, and abandoned this little power plant.
I'll tell you where I noticed it most during the years, like I went to Iowa in 1931 and then I took my mother down again in 1938.
When I was at Rosetown in 1937, that's on the main road north from Swift Current, that people were migrating up there.
In the spring of '38, I went out and relieved out at Gravelbourg in Lafleche while they changed operators out there.

entries.title: War, Marriage, and Construction
entries.description: The years 1939-1943 were marked by the outbreak of World War II, which significantly impacted Lindy's work and life, requiring him to be on constant call. He married in late 1940 and witnessed the construction of an airport in Estevan, Saskatchewan, a period of intense activity and demanding work.

excerpts.text: in any of the churches there of course i suppose the churches is you know the people in the church didn't have any money either so i suppose that would be well the church is the people put it that way. Yeah do you remember when it started to get better well yes about 1942,
And they were building an airport in Estevan, around '42, and ... one hell of a place to work.
Then the airport came in in 1941, so it was really a busy time around there.
Then I was in charge of the lines there for the rest of '37, '38, '39, '40.
And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month.

entries.title: Constant Vigil, Years of Duty
entries.description: The years 1944 and 1945 were marked by relentless on-call duty, demanding nearly every day of Lindy's time. This period likely involved significant professional responsibilities within Achen Construction, possibly related to wartime efforts or infrastructure projects. It was a time of intense pressure and commitment, preceding his later work building rural power lines.

excerpts.text: And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month.
It was in 45, '44.

entries.title: Prairie Contractor: Post-War Years
entries.description: In 1945, Lindy Achen transitioned to independent contracting, focusing on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He was actively bidding on projects and working with individuals like Ted Durnan, marking a significant period of business growth following years working for various companies. The end of 1945 and into 1946 saw him completing the airport and establishing himself in Regina.

excerpts.text: The tenders ranged - now this is in 1945 dollars. You can multiply that by five for today. The first tender opened up, $11,000; the next one, $11,500; the next one, $11,075, and then mine was the last one, $10,050. Well here I was just
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
The Fall of '45, when I finished the airport, I came into Regina here and did some work.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.
Now I'm a contractor on my own, and the time is the end of September 1945.

entries.title: Lines Across the Prairie
entries.description: The years 1946-1950 marked a period of significant expansion for Lindy's Achen Construction, focused on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He oversaw major projects, including a line to Stoughton, and faced challenges like labor strikes in northern regions. This era solidified his reputation as a key figure in electrifying the province.

excerpts.text: ,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.
We're talking now the end of 1945 and 1946, the '46 -
I built that big line to Stoughton in '46.
About '46, I think, companies taken over.
Yes, I even did some in 1945 or '46.

entries.title: Prairie Lines, A Man's Work
entries.description: In 1947, Lindy Achen was 45 years old and deeply involved in expanding Achen Construction's work, building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He managed multiple crews, overseeing projects like the line from Weyburn to Radville, and the year marked the end of a season of significant construction efforts.

excerpts.text: 1947, my first job was building a line from Weyburn to Radville and picking up the village of Trossachs on the way.
And as the funny says - Fools Hesitate, Funny McGee. Well, that was the end of 1947.
There's no interference from the wind, so I'll go on talking about 1947 now.
And I want to go back now to 1947, when I was running the two crews.
to finish up at Yorkton from the fall of '47.

entries.title: Shifting Gears, New Directions
entries.description: 1948 appears to be a pivotal year for Lindy Achen, marked by a sense of needing to 'make definite moves' and significant shifts in his work. He was actively involved in his construction business, struggling to recall specific projects, and relocating to Regina, likely in the spring. The year also seems connected to establishing prices for his work, suggesting a period of business development and potential challenges.

excerpts.text: and moved up here. It was still spring there was a lot of snow I think we come up about - maybe about the end of march or the middle of april sometime in there we moved to Regina. Now, I didn't have any work for '48 we had to tender. Well I still had a little work to finish up at Rosetown and a little
The spring of 1948, I could see then things were going to move ahead, and I had to make some definite moves.
The price had been established back in, when, '50 - '48 or '50, somewhere in there, had been established.
And I have to really think hard now to think of where I worked in '48. In '48...
And incidentally, I might mention that in 1948,

entries.title: Prairie Lines and High Voltage
entries.description: In 1949, Lindy Achen and Achen Construction were actively building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, Canada. His work involved significant projects like securing a high-voltage line from Killaly and constructing lines for numerous farms, demonstrating a period of intense labor and expansion for his company. Lindy was 47 years old during this time, continuing his career as an electrician and contractor.

excerpts.text: Another time we had built a line up in Alberta, I may have said that earlier. And Art Miller was up there. This was way back in '49.
And in '49, I went to - oh yeah, I got the piece of high voltage line, the 72,000 from Killaly,
Previous to that, in '49, I can't recollect where we were working.
From there, moved down to - oh, I forgot to tell you, in '49.
Well, anyway, that was the start of '49. Now I have -

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Union Roots
entries.description: The year 1950 marked a period of intense activity for Lindy Achen and Achen Construction, with significant power line projects spanning across Saskatchewan, from Yorkton to Bienfait and the Ogema-Shaunavon area. This year also saw the beginnings of a contractors' union, reflecting the evolving landscape of the industry and Lindy's involvement in it, while he continued to oversee large-scale construction projects and deal with labor disputes.

excerpts.text: anything that come up no matter what it was. And they let the other guys get by. Some of them set up little one-horse offices but didn't have anybody in there to man it, so they were no better off but that was one of the things they asked for and never got. But I don't know to relate back - Oh, we had a contractors' union. We started that way back in about 1950.

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the OgemaBengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
Then in '50, I started out. Built that line from Yorkton to Theodore and from there, Lampman to Bienfait, that was another 18 miles.
,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Growing Work
entries.description: The years 1950-1951 were a period of significant expansion for Lindy's construction business. He and his crew were heavily involved in building three-phase transmission lines and power lines across northern and southern Saskatchewan, covering vast distances and serving numerous towns. It was a 'big season' marked by substantial workload and a growing reputation for Achen Construction.

excerpts.text: And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the OgemaBengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
I set all the poles in all the suburbs that were built from 1951.
Yeah, then '51, then I got a whole bunch of line.
Big season that was in '51.

entries.title: Wiring the Prairie Farms
entries.description: In 1952, Lindy Achen's construction company began a significant expansion of rural power lines across Saskatchewan, connecting numerous farms to the electrical grid. This period marked a rapid increase in projects, with the number of farms served growing substantially year after year. It was a demanding time, characterized by long working seasons and a constant push to build infrastructure across the prairie landscape.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
We were out building all these lines in from - starting about '52 is when the farm program really started.
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.
And then '52 - and then the farms started picking up.

entries.title: Incorporation and Rapid Growth
entries.description: The years 1953-1956 marked a period of significant expansion for Lindy's business, with a rapid increase in the number of farms served and the construction of a new office and shop. This was also the year he incorporated Achen Construction, a pivotal moment that brought new challenges, particularly regarding his own compensation. The focus remained heavily on rural farms during this time.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
I built an office and a shop in '53, and it was too small the day I built it, and it's still operating.
And when I incorporated then in 1953, I didn't know what wages I should draw.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.

entries.title: Building Power on the Prairie
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of rapid expansion for Achen Construction, with the company significantly increasing the number of farms they electrified each year. Lindy, at 52, was deeply involved in this work, facing challenges like a devastating sleet storm that disrupted communication across southern Manitoba. This era marked a period of intense labor and growth for his company.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
Oh, in 1954, they had a big sleet storm in Manitoba, and they took down all the telephone lines in southern Manitoba.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
It was '54.

entries.title: Expansion, Farms, and a Crisis
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of significant expansion for Achen Construction, with the company rapidly increasing the number of farms they electrified each year. Lindy's work was intense, leading to a heart attack in 1955 that temporarily sidelined him. Despite the setback, the company continued its ambitious rural electrification project across Saskatchewan.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
In '55, when I had my heart attack, you know, I was right out of it.
And '55, well, we did some towns and villages in that, too.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
And I wasn't - In '55 and '56

entries.title: Powering the Prairie Landscape
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of significant expansion for Lindy's Achen Construction, as they dramatically increased the number of farms they electrified across Saskatchewan. Lindy, at 54 years old, oversaw a surge in productivity, with the company consistently exceeding previous years' farm electrification numbers. This era marked a peak in his career building rural power lines.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
And it went up to about 450 farms in '56.
I think we did about 600 farms in '56.
started about 1956 or 7, about '57.
We wound up, again, '56 more farms.

entries.title: Power Lines and Fading Farms
entries.description: Around 1957, Lindy's construction business was winding down a period of intense activity, having built significant infrastructure from 1952. He was transitioning from large-scale farm operations to more scattered work, while also continuing to build power lines for newly established farms in rural areas. This marked a shift in his focus and a move towards a different phase of his career.

excerpts.text: In 1957, we built power lines up there, and these were the people that had migrated up there into the woods, had it all cleared out, and had beautiful farms.
'57 now the farm operation the big units of 40 and 50 farms are pretty well all done. We're doing a scattered filling -
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
And I just finished saying that we were - in '57, we were filling in farms.
Well, after '57, I kept Art Miller in the shop to more or less

entries.title: Dust Settles, Business Shifts
entries.description: 1958 appears to have been a difficult year for Lindy, marked by a lack of work and being 'bit out' of projects, likely related to his construction business. He was experiencing a downturn, expanding his office, and dealing with the aftermath of events that left many of his men based in Regina. It was a period of transition and adjustment within his career.

excerpts.text: Yeah, when the dust was settled in '58, well, I had my men, most of them were in Regina here.
Well, anyway, to get back to '58, when I was bid right out, didn't have any work.
I expanded the office in 1958, I think it was,
When they opened their wide up in '58,
And I'm still talking back in '58.

entries.title: Prairie Power, A Quiet Year
entries.description: Around 1959, Lindy's Achen Construction was likely still actively building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, a task he undertook from 1945 to 1965. While he recalls some activity, Lindy describes 1959 as 'not a big year,' suggesting a period of relative calm or perhaps a lull in major projects within the broader scope of his work.

excerpts.text: And the next year, in '59, things started picking up again.
In '59, what did we do in 59?
Yeah, '59 was not a big year.
And we kept going, '59 -
And that completed '59.

entries.title: Building Lines, Bidding, and Years
entries.description: The early 1960s were a busy time for Lindy and Achen Construction, marked by significant line building projects and competitive bidding for high-voltage work. He continued to expand his business, constructing H-frame lines and tackling challenging river crossings. As the years progressed into 1963, Lindy found it increasingly difficult to recall the specifics of his work.

excerpts.text: Then in '61, Rags Johnson and ourselves jointly bid on a piece of high-voltage line from Shellbrook to Prince Albert, which had a river crossing in it, which was always a big job.
Then '63. Trying to think, in '63 - as the later years come come in it's harder for me to remember what the hell we were doing. And -
And then Con Bandy, another guy that started working for me in '63, or '62, somewhere in there.
'60 another one of those years where it was a little work here, and a little work there.
Then it come along '60 and I build - then I got quite a bit of line in '60.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Passing Years
entries.description: The years 1963 and 1964 found Lindy deeply involved in his construction business, continuing the work of building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. At 62 years old, he was likely reflecting on a life built from the prairie soil and the challenges of family relationships, as suggested by his earlier recollections. This period marked a transition point, nearing the end of his extensive power line construction career.

excerpts.text: That was '63 and '64.

entries.title: Retirement, Legacy, and Transition
entries.description: The years surrounding 1965 marked a significant turning point for Lindy Achen, as he sold his construction business and formally retired after a lifetime dedicated to building rural power lines. While he felt burned out, the transition involved establishing a new company with a partner, though Lindy retained a connection through the company's name and initial structure. This period represented a shift from active labor to a legacy of contribution and a move towards a new chapter in his life.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
I've enjoyed relatively good health, considering that when I quit, I - when I quit in 1965, I was pretty well burned out.
With Art - they set up a company, Achen '65 Limited, and Art was the 51% shareholder.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.

entries.title: Retreat and Reflection
entries.description: Around 1966, Lindy Achen was transitioning out of the construction business he had built over two decades. He sold his company between 1965 and 1967, marking a significant shift in his life after years of hard work and expansion across the Saskatchewan prairies. This period likely involved reflection on his accomplishments and planning for a new chapter.

excerpts.text: This is in '66 - yeah that's -
I sold out in '65, '66, '67.
